title: The Long Tail of ‘Kitten on the Keys’
sub_head: Recorded 100 years ago this month, Zez Confrey’s piano piece launched a zippy musical style.
body:
In February 1921, a composer-pianist with the quirky name Zez Confrey (from his middle name, Elzear) recorded an original piece that grabbed pianists and listeners by their ears, became a bestseller and left a permanent imprint on American music. “Kitten on the Keys” heralded a fresh, zippy style of music dubbed novelty piano.
Like his near-contemporary and fellow virtuoso George Gershwin, Confrey grounded himself in both classical and popular idioms. After studying at a Chicago conservatory, Confrey whetted his keyboard skills by arranging player-piano rolls of pop music, embellishing notes and enriching harmonies. His roll work—about 170 pieces—remains an effervescent emblem of the 1920s. He went on to compose a variety of popular works, but he has been largely and unjustifiably forgotten.
